{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3370706,"name":"","username":"InPlainSight","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-23T13:31:35.924Z","cooked":"

This can be from literally any subgroup, from Cad design to outreach. Can also be more general. I’ve used the NASA rap sheet, but I’m looking to see if there are other well used ones. Can also be videos, YouTube channels, anything.

Here are some of the guides that really helped me:

robotics.nasa.gov

nasarap-rdc-v101-compressed.pdf

13.50 MB

https://spectrum3847.org/recommendedreading/

paper: Robotics Instruction Course CD-Media: Papers
Thread created automatically to discuss a document in CD-Media. Robotics Instruction Course by: Redhead Jokes _Our Northrop Robotics’ Engineer and his fellow mentors are teaching this course each Sunday, open to FIRST teams. "This document is written to accompany a course of instruction in robotics fundamentals for high school students participating in a competitive robotics team. Our intent in prepa…_ Our Northrop Robotics’ Engineer and his fellow mentors are teaching this course each Sunda…

http://www.team610.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Design-TutorialsRev10.pdf

What should new teams be doing? General Forum
Read: Watch: The Spartan Series videos Do: Visit other teams Talk with other local teams Practice prototyping - look on Chief for the prototyping resources Practice CAD - Onshape Practice Code - I don’t mentor programming so… Practice some wiring - make sure that the way you guys want to wire is done correctly and reliably. Something that might be useful is to find a kit of parts chassis that someone will lend to you so that you guys can dry run assembling, wiring, and …

They have a lot more than just training materials as well.

If your team is using Onshape for CAD I reccomend checking out their built in learning center and if your team is not using Onshape for CAD I’d consider switching over. They have some nice self paced courses and even courses made for FRC.

If you have students that are brand new to programming I reccomend trying out the University of Helsinki’s free programming course

1678 also publishes a great set of workshops every year that cover all kinds of topics

Spectrum also has a great video about design organization along with many other helpful videos

I’d also highly reccomend checking out some Open Alliance build logs from both this year and previous years. Some of my favorites from this year:

6328 - Mechanical Advantage

3847 - Spectrum

7407 - Wired Boars

3467 - Windham Windup

For programming, one of the resources I started with that helped me a lot was a YouTube channel named FRC 0 to Autonomous. They only have 6 videos, and you need to know a little bit about Java programming with FRC first, but it provides some good information to get started and get deeper. I especially recommend their explanation of PID, as it’s very clear and concise, even for me, who knew nothing about it at the time.

YouTube

FRC 0 to Autonomous

Share your videos with friends, family, and the world

Here are some docs 2024 rookies have put together; interesting perspective because it’s directly what other rookies have found valuable.
FRC 9477 (Lambda) has this: https://roboticslhs.wixsite.com/lambert-robotics/lambda-resources
FRC 9496 (Lynk) has this: https://docs.lynkrobotics.org/

In the last offseason, 1678 released some great resources that I shared with a lot of the newer members of our team.

1678 Citrus Circuits Training Resources Release Robotics Education and Curriculum
Team 1678 Citrus Circuits is excited to release our new 2023 training resources! Our student leads have been working hard to put together these documents to help supplement the off-season training process. This link provides access to a view-only Google Drive folder including resources from these subteams: Primary Subteams Hardware Design Hardware Fabrication Hardware Electrical Software Scouting Software Robot Business and Media Secondary Subteam Strategy 1678 Training Resources 2023 Pl…
","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T14:15:55.502Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":48.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464144,"topic_slug":"what-are-the-best-guides-tutorials-you-would-recommend-to-a-rookie-team","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1678-citrus-circuits-training-resources-release/440322","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"1678 Citrus Circuits Training Resources Release","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-the-best-guides-tutorials-you-would-recommend-to-a-rookie-team/464144/10","custom_user_title":"Programming & Electrical Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372386,"name":"Lance Handkammer","username":"Lancerjh","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lancerjh/{size}/177439_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T17:12:13.104Z","cooked":"

Yeti (3506) robotics has a series of YouTube tutorials that detail and demonstrate how to effectively design and build west coast drive. I know that west coast has kind of fallen off and become a less popular drive base but if your team is considering using a west coast drive base then I would recommend those videos as they are super helpful.

A lot of people have provided good resources.

The number one thing I think is important for a rookie team is to find a strong experienced team in their area and work closely with them. The problem for rookie teams without FRC experience is that you’re starting from such a knowledge deficit that you won’t know which resources are most helpful and applicable to you. They can teach how successful FRC teams operate (i.e. it’s more than building a robot), and identify areas where you can make easy improvements, and help shore up areas where you don’t have knowledge.

The senior mentor in your area will probably be the best way to find a team with the capacity to help you.

A lot of what is most important for a rookie team isn’t knowledge about how to build a robot but more knowledge about how to build and run a team. To this end, I’d recommend three resources:

  • Spectrum’s FIRST $10000, which has a list of tools to buy for a new team.

  • 1678’s Strategic Design talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches the season.

  • Mike Corsetto’s Building a Student Leadership Culture talk, which will walk you through how 1678 approaches team leadership. This one might be more important after your rookie year.
